default.prompt: Which directive is used to reactively update an HTML attribute, such as 'src' or 'disabled'?
default.explanation: v-bind (shorthand ':') is used to bind an attribute to an expression. For example, :disabled='isPending' will apply the disabled attribute if isPending is truthy.
default.interviewTip: In Vue 3.4+, you can use the shorthand :id instead of :id='id' if the attribute name matches the variable name.

options: The word 'Hello' in default black text
default.explanation: v-html updates the element's innerHTML with the provided string. Use this with caution as it can lead to XSS attacks.
default.interviewTip: Always warn about XSS when discussing v-html; only use it on trusted content.

default.prompt: What is the difference between {{ message }} and v-text="message"?
options: {{ }} allows for partial content replacement; v-text replaces the entire textContent of the element.
v-text supports HTML tags; {{ }} does not.
There is no difference; they are exactly the same.
default.explanation: Interpolation (Mustaches) allows you to mix text and variables like 'Hello {{ name }}'. v-text will overwrite everything inside the tag with the variable's value.
default.interviewTip: Mustaches are preferred for readability, while v-text is rarely used unless you want to avoid 'Flash of Uncompiled Template' (though v-cloak is better for that).

default.prompt: How do you listen to DOM events (like a click) and run some JavaScript when they are triggered?
default.explanation: v-on (shorthand '@') is the directive for event listeners. It can call a method or run an inline expression.
default.interviewTip: Mention event modifiers like @click.prevent or @click.stop for handling common event logic declaratively.

default.prompt: Which directive creates a two-way data binding on form input, textarea, and select elements?
default.explanation: v-model is 'syntactic sugar' that combines v-bind (to set the value) and v-on (to listen for input changes).
default.interviewTip: In Vue 3, you can have multiple v-models on a single custom component (e.g., v-model:first-name and v-model:last-name).

default.prompt: Which of the following directives are used to optimize performance by skipping re-renders or compilation?
options: v-once (renders the element only once and skips future updates)
v-pre (skips compilation for this element and its children)
v-memo (memoizes a sub-tree of the template based on dependencies)
v-static (forces the component to never change)
default.explanation: v-once and v-memo are for runtime performance. v-pre is for compile-time performance, allowing you to show raw mustache tags without Vue processing them.
default.interviewTip: v-memo is a powerful Vue 3.2+ feature specifically for optimizing large v-for lists.

default.interviewTip: Modifiers like .trim and .lazy are also vital for refining user input behavior without extra JS logic.

default.prompt: What is the result of using a JavaScript expression inside mustaches, like {{ number + 1 }}?
options: It will throw an error; only variable names are allowed.
It will evaluate the expression and render the result.
It will render the expression as a string.
default.explanation: Vue supports full JavaScript expressions inside data bindings, but they must be single expressions (no statements or flow control).
default.interviewTip: While expressions are powerful, keep them simple. If logic gets complex, move it to a 'computed' property.

default.prompt: What is the purpose of the 'v-cloak' directive?
options: To hide elements until Vue has finished compiling, preventing the flash of uncompiled template (FOUC).
To make the element invisible permanently.
default.explanation: v-cloak stays on the element until the Vue instance finishes compiling. You typically pair it with CSS like [v-cloak] { display: none } to hide mustache tags during page load.
default.interviewTip: This is mainly useful for server-rendered HTML where the template is visible before Vue hydrates.

default.prompt: How do you dynamically bind a directive argument in Vue 3?
options: Use square brackets around the argument name to make it dynamic.
default.explanation: Dynamic directive arguments (introduced in Vue 2.6+) allow you to use a JavaScript expression as the directive argument by wrapping it in square brackets.
default.interviewTip: This is useful for creating generic components that can bind to different events or attributes based on props.
